Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth,and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening befor.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon,the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivving in London at the very conveniant hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is L22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
To The East.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: THE REVOLUTION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: The situation in Russia does not show any improvement. On every side there is chaos, and every day the condition of Russia goees from worse to worse, and the startling evidences of organisation that are provided by the wholesale extent of the area of revolt are driving many observers to "hail the dawn" for Russia as Fox did for France. The revolutionary movement has been compared to that which took place in France after the assemblage of the States-General: and the parallel is a striking, and in many respects a just one. But if the Russians, as has been remarked, have greater difficulties to face before they can achieve freedom, since they have not even the tradition of it, and no feeling of national unity such as animated France, there is one point on which they possess an enormous advantage. Throughout the French Revolution the Roman Catholic Church was practically a negligible quantity: if it attracted attention, it was only because it inspired the passionate hate of the Mountain, and the ridicule of the Sansculottes. But the Church in Russia has played a part that it has never attempted in Western Europe. Since the Empire was established a thousand years ago, it has been in the van of every national movement. It has blessed the expeditions against the Tartars and the Turks; it has endeavored to be the protector of all the Oriental Christians; it has sympathised with the peasant in his distress, and at times it has formulated the Imperial policy. But last January it was a priest of the Church who led the workmen at St. Petersburg: and it is significant in the highest degree that the clergy seem now to have abandoned the Government. If they, whose influence is naturally exerted in favor of the Autocracy, turn against it, what can be expected of that vast mass of people who are wavering in their allegiance, and what excesses may not be anticipated from those who have already decided on Revvolution as the one thing needful to save their country? The fate of Russia lies in her own hands. Whether a measure of popular control is to bbe the ultimate rule for the Muscovite Empire rests with the people. The sole result visible at present iis complete stagnation of commerce, and absolute chaos everywhere. Until her internal affairs are decided, Russia will hardly count among the Councils of the Great Powers: and the situation, unfortunately, reacts on the rest of Europe disastrously, not only so far as business is concerned, but in graver fashion as giving dangerous opportunities for ambition elsewhere.

div.head: ENGLAND AND RUSSIA. A POLITICAL ENTENTE PAVING THE WAY.
div.p: London, November 14.

Renter’s Agency is authoritatively informed that the friendliest discussions are going on between Great Britain and Russia, with a view to eliminating the obstacles in the way of negotiations for a political entente, when the time is ripe for the latter ; but definite political steps are inopportune while the present | disturbed state of Russia continues. It is felt, however, that it is already possible to pave the way, by the revision of the commercial treaty, in view of closer commercial relations. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH DOCKYARD STRIKE. ATTITUDE OF GOVERNMENT.
div.p: PARIS, November 14.
The dockyard employés at Toulon, Brest, Rochefort, and Cherbourg will strike to-day.
(Reuter)
PARIS, November 14.
The strike in the French dockyards has begun without disorder. Except at Toulon arsenal, the strike is only partial.
(Reuter)
PARIS, November 14.
The strike is general at Toulon and partial at Brest and Cherbourg.
A circular issued by M. Thomson, Minister, assimilates the strike to desertion. The strikers will be struck off the lists.
M. Reuvier stated in the Senate that the Government would resist the strike. This statement was received with applause.
(Havas)

div.head: THE POWERS AND THE PORTE. THE NAVAL DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, November 14.
It is understood that before making a naval demonstration the Powers will notify the Sol- tan of their preparations, in the hope that he may listen to reason at the last moment. (R.)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN CRISIS. RESTORING ORDER.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG. November 14.
The Governors of Odessa, Esthonia, Perm, Tomsk, and Kezan have been dismissed for not having prevented the massacres. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, November 14.

The Tsar is sending aides-de-camps armed with dictatorial powers to restore order in the governments of Tehermigoff, Saratoff, and Tamboff, where disorders between the town and rural populations still continue.
There were a hundred killed in a small town in the government of Ekaterinoslav. (Reuter)

div.head: TO PROTECT AMERICAN CITIZENS.
div.p: LISBON, November 14.
It is stated that the American cruiser Minneapolis, now here, has received urgent orders to proceed to Kronstadt to protect American citizens. Marines will be disembarked if necessary.
(Reuter)

div.head: MASS MEETING IN LONDON.
div.p: LONDON, November 14.

A mass meeting has been held at the Memorial Hall to protest against the Russian atrocities A telegram was read from Mr. Balfoar stating that the Government had beard with pity and horror of the massacres of Jews, and bad already taken every step that seems possible to mitigate the calamity. Lord Rose¬bery, Mr. Chamberlain, Mr. Asquith, Lord Rothschild, the Archbishops of Canterbury and Westminster, and other prominent men sent similar telegrams.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE ENTENTE MUNICIPAL. FRENCH INVITATION TO L.C.C.
div.p: LONDON, November 14.
The County Council has received the most cordial invitation from the Paris Municipal Council to visit Paris in January. (Reuter)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Brindisi Mail.
The Brindisi mail will arrive at Alexandria this afternoon and be distributed at the G.P.O. at 5 p.m.
Stray Dogs.
Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Sayeda Zenab quarter of Cairo during the night of the 16th inst will be poisoned by the police.
Asphalting in Cairo.
Fagalish street, Cairo, is to be asphalted next year. During the progress of the work the trams will run by a new route for the time being.
Fatal Tram Accident
An Arab boy six or seven years old was ran over by a tramcar this morning near the corner of Sisters street and Mohamed Aly square. The child was killed on the spot.
British Manufacturers’ Exhibition.
A general meeting in connection with the proposed exhibition of British manufactures will be held at H.B.M.’s Consulate, Alexandria, on Tuesday, 21st inst., at 4.30 p.m.
Fire on Ship.
The S.S. Westburn, which arrived at Alexandria on Monday with a fire on board, has begun discharging her cargo of coal The fire in the hold has been almost extinguished.
Murder st Tantah.
While George Avrinos and Yanui Konatns, two residents of Tantah, were drinking together in a bar on Sunday, a dispute arose between them which ended in the former stabbing his companion fatally.
Suez Canal.

16 vessels passed through the Canal on the 10th and 14th inst., 18 of which were British, 4 German, 2 French, 1 Austrian, 1 Portuguese. The total receipts from the 1st to the 11th inst were frs. 3,683,898.06.
Fikis at Alexandria.
The Khedive has given orders for the creation of three committees cf fikis for reading the Koran in the mosques of Alexandria. The incomes of these three committees have been fixed at LE. 700 a year.
Journalists Imprisoned.

The Court of Sayeda Zenab, Cairo, has sen¬tenced Ahmed Eff. Abbas and Reghib Eff. Hassad, editors of "El Khalan," and Abd-El- Medjid Eff. Kamel, editor of the Egyptian "Papagallo,” to six months' imprisonment for libelling Ibrahim Eff. Shaker, an advocate of Cairo.
El Dorado.

Alexandrians will be glad to hear that M. Conegliano has transformed the summer garden bordering on his new establishment in Cairo Station street into a winter garden. Mr. Conegliano neglects nothing to satisfy the desires of his patrons, and the El Dorado should soon become the most frequented rendezvous in the city.
Scorpions at Keneh.

Owing to the many deaths from scorpions in Keneh and its neighborhood, a society was formed some time ago for the purpose of putting an end to the pest, and a reward of two milliemes for each scorpion killed was offered. From the end of May to the end of October last 4,990 scorpions had been destroy¬ed at Keneh.
Shepheard's Hotel.

From to-day a general booking office will be open at Shepheard’s Hotel for the issue of 1st and 2nd class railway passenger tickets and forwarding of luggage by passenger trains to the destination of Alexandria, Ismailia, Port Said, and Luxor during the tourist season. In addition to the general tariff rates, an extra charge of 5 milliemes on every passenger ticket and on every 100 kilos of luggage, or fraction of same, will be made on all bookings from this office.
Relieving his Conscience.

Elias el Absi, an inmate of Tantah prison, has written to the Parquet stating that, being desirous of relieving his conscience, he wishes to confess the following crimes, which have hitherto been unknown to the authorities. He murdered, he says, a sheikh el Arab, by name Lemboon el Saadi, near Magbaghs, in the Minieh moudirieh, and sold a plot of land belonging to the Government, in the Sharkieh moudirieb, to a native, pretending that he was a delegate of the Ministry of Finance. An enquiry has been opened by the authorities.
Nile Trip.

The Anglo American Nile Steamer and Hotel Co. announce that their first departure from Cairo to Assouan, for the twenty days' trip, will take place on the 8th December next, by the first-class tourist steamer Mayflower. Though the company's lowest rate for tourists is £49, yet residents will be afforded a special opportunity to travel by the Mayflower at the exceptionally reduced rate of watch will include a first-class table, all sight-seeing expenses, excursions, dragoman,&c. The Government permit of £1.4 8. is not included in the above fare.
Burnt to Death.

A Berberin, employed as a servant in one of the flats attached to the National Hotel, Cairo, went to sleep on Monday night and awoke to find his clothes on fire. Seized with panic the wretched man ran op and down the stain calling for help. Mr. Rozensweig, of the Minis try of Public Works, extinguished the flames, and the man, who did not receive any useful assistance from his fellow servants,was conveyed to hospital in a carriage which had been sent for by a British resident. The shock from his injuries bad been too great, however and he succumbed yesterday morning.

div.head: SALT AND SODA. QUESTION OF THE CONCESSION. EXCITEMENT ON BOURSES.
div.p: The great excitement which was display¬ed on the Alexandria and Cairo Bourses yesterday, in the rash to dispose of Salt and Soda shares, was renewed this morning, when a further fall took place and lens of thousands of shares were disposed of. At midday some strong buyers appeared on the market and a slight recovery took place. The shares closed when we went to press at 24s. 6d.

It is stated that the Egyptian Government has withdrawn the salt concession, but that there are grounds for believing that an arrangement will be arrived at between the company and the Government, so that a modus vivendi may be established. This news is, however, not official, but merely the substance of what is alleged on the Alexandria Bourse.

Lord Cromer’s remarks on the subject in his last Report are worthy of quotation at the present juncture. His lordship says "I regard this (the salt monopoly) as one of the greatest of the remaining blots on the existing fiscal system. A country lest adapted for a monopoly of salt than Upper Egypt can hardly be imagined. The desert is full of salt, which can be had for the trouble of taking it away. In the long narrow strip of inhabited land, there are but few villages which are far from some salt deposit Smuggling, of course, takes place and it is practically impossible to stop it. In 1904, 1,716 cases of contraband occurred; the number of persons fined or imprisoned was 1,223. In the remaining cases, the salt was seized, and the animals used in smuggling were confiscated. The number of animals thus confiscated was 489. The offenders rarely, if ever pay the fines imposed, and, I conceive, do not much mind being imprisoned for a short t mo. Confiscation of the animals is probably a more severe punishment, as it must often reduce the culprits, who are all very poor, to a state of indigence. Although no domiciliary visits are ever made to search for salt, it cannot be doubted that the measures taken to repress the contraband trade axe rightly regarded by the population as oppressive. I hope, therefore, that the financial situation will, at tome future time, permit of a Urge reduction in the royalty now paid on salt A small reduction would merely involve a loss of revenue, and would not lead to any considerable increase of consumption.”

The revenue derived from the salt monopoly in 1904 was L.E. 182,000 as compared to L.E. 169,000 in 1903 ; 60,000 tons of salt were consumed. This is at about the rate of 5.4 kilos, per head of population. The normal consumption in most European countries is considerably higher than this figure.

Prior to 1892, all salt was sold direct by the Government at a price of P.T. 800 a ton. It is now sold by the company at P.T. 500 a ton. The Government receive a royalty out of this sum of no less than P.T. 310 a ton.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: The Egyptian Estates, Limited, have made a moat successful deal in the disposal of a fine block of land of 4,950 square metres with a frontage of 150 metres, to Messrs Walker and Meimarachi,Limited, in the Ismailia quarter of Cairo, near the Credit Ponder and the E.T.C. The Egyptian Estates bought the land at LE. 10 per square metre and sold it at L E. 15. Immediately after the purchase Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi were offered LE. 20, but refused to entertain this. The profit in the transaction realised by the Egyptian Estates accounts to close on £25,000.

div.head: NEW BANKS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Wiener Bank Verein intends to commence backing operations in Egypt shortly. This bank’s two new branches at Gatala and Stamboul will be opened on January 1. As soon as these branches have been opened and are in working order, the direction of the bank will busy itself with the foundation of its new branches at Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: PRO BONO PUBLICO ?
div.p: A Cairo French contemporary announces that Mr. Terah Hooley and Mr. Horatio Bottomley are coming to Egypt this season. Oar contemporary adds : Nos hôtes, qui comp- tent parmi les rois de la finance anglaise, »e proposent d''étudier l'opportunité de contribuer au mouvement industriel du pays.’’

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Roman Prince, from Manchester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Tuesday, and is doe to arrive at Alexandria on the 18th inst.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES. THE POUTREL-DAVEY ACTION.
div.p: At 10 a.m. yesterday the 2nd Chambre Civile of the Cairo Mixed Court was asleep, or st least nodding : oases of small importance Ironed along— some of the members of the Bench were obviously drowsy and the audience bored. At last Judge Herzbruch called the Poutrel Davey case,—No. 50 on the roll sod the audience and Bench awoke in earnest Me. Guilhanmon opened the case for his client shortly before 11 a.m. and for the next forty minutes kept the Court interested, for his speech contained some most interesting passages described in piteons terms the plight of M. Poutrel, summoned from Europe by an urgent wire and dismissed within three hours of bis arrival at Cairo, and then discussed the reasons of his dismissal. Obviously, the Hon. A. J. Davey and others bad sought a scapegoat and M. Poutrel had been selected for this office : the whole beard had done its utmost to escape from the incubus of their responsibility for the crash, some had failed, and the Hon. A J. Davey's attempts could impose on no one. How could he explain sway the letter that ha had written to his colleagues on the board ? -the letter containment the statement of Mr. X, who informed the Hon. A. J. Davey in the Turf Club that Sir Ernest Cassel had told him in the presence of Birch Pasha many things, and this among others, that if he did not take the Sucreries in hand a smash was inevitable, and that he did not know how they got their dividends and meant to go into the question.”

Counsel for the defence suggested that the letter might as well be produced. Mr. Guilhaumon declined, but stated that he believed in its existence and contained to take its most interesting passages as his text All, be said. pointed to the fact that the Hon. A. J. Davey knew all and had known all along before the crash, nor did he fail to avail himself of other arguments. Defendant had signed the balance- sheets, could he have possibly been ignorant of their true meaning? And much more to that effect. Then back to the famous letter : it existed, so he believed, but he would not produce it, and so saying he sat down at 11.35 a.m and Mo. Carton de Wiart took up the defence.

Then came the first sensation Counsel for the defence would like to know whether plaintiff’s counsel had seen the original or the copy of the letter. A brief verbal skirmish followed, and then Me. Carton de Wiart startled the Court and the audience by the statement that the letter had been stolen "with effraction” from the Sugar Company’s safe, to which Me. Guilhaumon retorted that be was not the Public Prosecutor.

Then came the defence. M Poutrel was bringing a personal action, but the Hon. A J. Davey had acted as he had done in his official capacity of administrator delegate, acting manager, in fact, of the whole business. On September 2l, he had written officially to the board concerning M. Poutrel, and the board had given him carte blanche to dismiss M. Poutrel or accept his resignation. The letter was there, and what evidence could be clearer? Then came another incident Me. Guilhaumon claimed that the letter had not been communicated to him. “No," replied Me. Carton de Wiart, "it was communicated to you last night,” and added that he had himself written to the papers on the subject stating that the Hon. A. J. Davey's conduct bad been approved by the hoard, and that Me. Guilhaumon bad replied also in the columns of the Press. Counsel for the plaintiff argued that tie Press was not the proper medium for the communication of documents. Counsel for defendant replied briskly and then Me Guilhaumon, on the ground that he had not studied or seen the document, asked for the postponement of the hearing. It was granted, and shortly before midday a most interesting trial was over—for the time.
We regret that owing to an error in the telephonic transmission of yesterday's account of the proceedings, Me. Guilhaumon's name appeared as Me. Pangalo

div.head: CAIRO IMPROVEMENTS.
div.p: According to a native contemporary the Finance Ministry has transmitted to the Public Works Ministry the application of a group of European financiers for the lotting of the lands lying to the west of the Pyramids of Ghizeh, with a view to forming a new suburb.

It is ???? a? that an Anglo-Egyptian company is negotiating for the purchase of the tumble-down dwellings in Boulao, which they would demolish and in their place build houses replete with every modern comfort.

div.head: DRAGOMANS AT SUEZ.
div.p: The new tariff for dragomans at Suez is to be as follows :— Milliemes 60 per hour for first three hours. Milliemes 30 for every supplemetary hour after the first three hours. Milliemes 250 for a whole day in the town and milliemes 300 for a whole day outside the town.

div.head: HASHISH SMOKING.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has sent a circular to the governors and moudirs throughout Egypt enjoining them to send every year on the 1st January to the Ministry of the In¬terior, reports on cases of hashish intoxication. Hitherto their reports have been sent on 18th February of every year.

div.head: RUN TO FARTH. SMART CAPTURE OF BRIGAND.
div.p: About eight yean ego a case of highway robbery and murder occurred in the Mariont district, which at that time was in the Kafr Dawar marker. A Bedouin, of the name of Abou Shalot, belonging to a family notorious for its lawlessness, was accused of the crime. He could not be found, so he was sentenced in his absence to penal servitude for life.

The police have been persistently looking for him ever since, and about three years ago a rumour was brought to their ears that this man was lurking in the neighbourhood. The police officer in charge of the district, Abdul Axim Wahbi Effendi, went out into the desert on the criminal’s trail, but Abou Shalot laid an ambush for him and badly wounded the officer and placed a shawish and a naffir hors de combat, while he succeeded in making good his escape.

For the last two years, since the Alexandria police have taken over the Mariont district, they have never ceased to look out for Shalot and on Monday morning, owing to secret in-formation, the mamour of the district, with an armed patrol of smart Sudanese policemen, went off eastwards from Amrieh and found Shalot in a home, waiting for them with a gun in his hand He was disarmed before he could do any damage, and was brought into Alexandria Yesterday in irons by an armed escort.
The mamour and police of the Mariont district are to be congratulated on having so successfully run to earth such a dangerous criminal after so many years of search.

div.head: GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS.
div.p: All the stories about the departure or changes of functions on the part of prominent English officials,which have appeared in the columns of our contemporaries, are devoid of foundation in fact.

div.head: HELLENIC NATIONALITY.
div.p: It is reported that some discoveries have been made of a remarkable series of frauds for famishing Greek rayahs. domiciled in Egypt, with papers purporting to prove their Hellenic nationality.

div.head: THE NEW ASYLUM.
div.p: A site covering about 120,000 square metres has been chosen for the new asylum and its grounds in the desert near Khanke. Some 600 patients will bo accomodated in the new building, and the pressure on the Abbassieh , Asylum will he greatly relieved by its erection.

div.head: RUSSIAN CONSULAR CHANGES.
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent informs us that M. Tobirkoff, secretary to the Russian | Consulate at Alexandria, has been appointed to a poet at Mitrovitza, to replace M. Kohmansky, himself transferred to the consulate- general at Salonica in place of M. Basilewaky, who has been appointed Russian Consul at Rio de Janeiro

div.head: PASTEUR INSTITUTE.
div.p: The selection of the new director of the Pasteur Institute at Cairo has been made by the Public Health Department, and is now awaiting the approval of the Government

div.head: NEW BRITISH CLUB.
div.p: It is expected there will be a large gathering of members of the British community in Alexandria at the meeting in the ETC. quarters this evening of those interested in the formation of the proposed British Club. It is unfortunate that this meeting and the meeting of the, A L M & D. S. should have been arranged for the same evening, but members of the latter society will have finished their business in ample time to attend the dub meeting which takes place at 9.15 p.m.

div.head: NEW CAIRO HOTEL
div.p: The Swiss Hotels Company has just registered at the Cairo Mixed Tribunal the deed of purchase of the lands situated on the Kaer-el- Nil esplanade at the price of LE 10 per square metre. The work of building the new hotel to be constructed there will be begun before the new year.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR
div.p: This first-class hotel, which has been thoroughly renovated, will open for the reason on the 20th inst. It is now under the management of Mersre. G. and M Runkewits. proprietors of the Beau-Rivage Hotel at Ramleh. This fact is a guarantee that at the Savoy Hotel. Luxor, visitors will find every comfort conducive to a pleasant stay. The hotel is near to a11 places of interest, with their many ruins and temples. The situation of the hotel on the river bank, with a view of the Nile traffic and beautiful surroundings, also adds to the charm of the hostelry. Special care has been taken to provide an excellent cuisine and cellar, the services of a well known chef have been secured, and a reliable service throughout has been instituted by the management. A number of applications have already been received from visitors who will pot up at the Savoy for some weeks.

div.head: THE CATTLE PLAGUE. NO EXTENSION IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: We are officially informed that the statement as to the increase of cattle plague in the Eastern Sudan is without foundation. Bovine typhus at present is confined to the Ashram district, on the borders of Erythrea, a remote and thinly populated region, and it is hoped that police measures will soon bring t he epidemic under. In any case, so far from there being an increase of cattle plague, the latest returns show a marked diminution in the number of cases.

div.head: THE CATTLE MARKETS.
div.p: On the 22nd inst., the cattle markets in Upper and Lower Egypt will he opened again, and for this purpose the country has been divided into four veterinary divisions, as follows :
1. Moudiriehs: Assouan, Keneh, Ghirgah, and Assiont; inspector, Mr. Trydell, at Assiout.
2. Moudiriehs: Mirieb, Benj-Souef, Fayoum and Ghizah ; inspector, Mr. Milner, at Cairo.
3. Mondiriehs : Galionbieh, Charkieh, Dakahlieh, Talkha marker, Cherbin, Suez Canal and Damietta ; inspector, Mr. Cooper, at Mansourah.
4. Moudiriehs : Menoufieb, B hera and the marker of Tanta, Zifta, Mehella, Santa, Kafr e1 Sheikh, Dessouk, Kafr el Zayat and Alexandria ; inspector, Mr. Herbert Mason, at Tantah.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: We understand that the escort of the Holy Carpet will this year be composed of half a battalion of regular Egyptian troops, instead of a provisional force of Reservists, as was the case last year. We need not dilate on the obvious advantages of this arrangement, and hope to be in a position to furnish our readers with details of the composition of the force in the near future.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS NEAR ABOUKIR
div.p: Professor Fliuders Petrie is shortly expected to arrive at Alexandria, in order to undertake some excavations in the vicinity of Aboukir.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: ( Communication Officielle)
Le Délégation Munierinsie s'est réunie le 14 novembre 1905 h 9 h. du soir sous la présidence de Mr. Amb Ralli.
Présents : MM. P. Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef. Soliman Bey Abani, E Stross, G. Zervudachi, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur , A. Willner, secrétaire p.i.

Eu raison de Il'encombrement de la voie publique à Minet-el-Bassal, et déférant au désir exprimé à ce sujet par 1'Alexandria Produce Association, la Délégation décide d’interdire toute occupation dans ce quartier at de neplus délivrer de roksas à cet égard.

La Délégation proposera a la Commission l’ouverture d’un crédit supplémentaire de LE 200 pour le service du balayage, en raison des déspenses imprévues nécessites par le nettoyage des maisons infectées par la peste.
Elle adjuge à Mr.V. di Bari, plus has offrant, au prix de LB. 824,les travaux d’empierrement de la rue de la Promenade, depuis la route de Siouf jusqu'à la rue Scambali, à Ramleh.

La Délégation examieners, à l'occasion de la discussion du budget de 1906, une demands de la Société Artistique tendant à accorder une allocation au Théâtra Zizinis pour la saison prochaine et à porter cette allocation à LE 1,000.

La Délégation décide de communiquer au Gouvernorat, sv. re avis favorable, sauf pour la durée demandée, one requéte de M. Santi Boni tendant à l'installation d’un bain à proximité des terrains dits “Bains Cléopatra,” à Ramleh.

La Délégation ajourne, comms prématurés, une demande tends tfa la location do terrain occupé par le Port Kail Bey, à l’effiet d’y errer et exploiter no grand hotel-restaurant, aveu établissements baluéaire, café et concert.
L’Adminisitrateur déposa sou rapport sur le budget de 1906.
Ce rapport sera distribué à tout les membres, en vue de sou examan à une prochaine sésnce.
La séance est levée â 11 h. 1/2 p-m.

div.head: GERMAN INFLUENCE IN BELGIUM.
div.p: A remarkable article from the pen of M. Schwob, a writer whose articles inspire confidence, appears in the "Aurore" (Paris), and is reproduced in part in the "Times." It suggests that the German economic conquest of Antwerp heralds the military conquest of the great Belgian seaport.

M. Schwob says that all Frenchmen will read with keen anxiety the results of his minute inquiry giving the details of the German occupation, which will gradually extend to all Belgium. They will see that a fifth of the members of the Chamber of Commerce at Antwerp are Germans, the president is of German origin and vice-president is a recently naturalised German. All its committees are invaded by Germans, eight having German chairmen, three others German vice-chairmen,and two with a completely German official staff. It is the same with the arbitration chambers. In addition to the list of avowed German firms in all branches of trade, which muster over 320 out of a total of about 1,550, M. Schwob says it is impossible for him to enumerate all the business houses which they control indirectly.

"As a great part of our merchandise passes through Antwerp it is watched, manipulated and labelled by them," writes Mr.Schwob, referring, of course, to French commerce. "They take note of our clients and of theirr tastes and then one fine day our custom will be stolen from us by skilful imitations at a reduced price. Even the banking business is invaded. Out of 14 administrators of the Central Bank in Antwerp, six, including the president and vice-president, are German."
M. Schwob further observes that the Germans are repeating the samme process at Rotterdam, but more slowly and with greater difficulty, owing to the more effective resistance offered by the Dutch.

div.head: JAP COTTON MANUFACTURES.
div.p: The experiments now being carried on by the Tokio Government, with a view to rendering Japan more independent of Indian and American suppliies of raw cotton, have a very living interest for Lancashire. Should success crown the endeavor, the close proximity of the islands to China will necessarily give their cotton manufactures a great advantage in that almost limitless market.Our allies already possess the other leading requisites for supplying Chinese requirements. The cotton cloths they manufacture are both moderate in price and very durable, while the Japanese mill-hand willingly accepts wages on which Lancashire operatives would half-starve. They also work much longer hours, and their natural ingenuity in design gives them additional advantage. Up to the present, however, the still infant industry has been heavily handicapped by such an insufficiency of the raw material that nearly a million sterling per annum has had to be paid in gold for imports. The central purpose, therefore, of the Marquis Ito's personal inquiry in Korea is to ascertain whether that new appanage of Japan can be depended on to eke out the cotton producing resources of the islands. It will be seen that the object is much the same as that of the English Cotton Growing Association- the prevention of "cornering" by foreign speculators whenever the extraneous supply seems likely to run short of the world's wants.

div.head: ARE DISEASES INCREASING?
div.p: There can be no question, says the "Practitioner," that the prevalence of certain diseases has increased during the last half century. Conspicuous among these are diabetes and insomnia, both of which are largely due to the mental stress of a harder struggle for existence. The increased consumption of alcohol, and the free use of narcotics, are also responsible for many morbid conditions unknown to our hardier forbears. But, in comparing the present prevalence of diseases with that of the past, there are several facotrs for which due allowance is often not made. One of thses is that our forefathers died, as a rule, at a considerably younger age than thei descendants; if they did not perish by the sword, they were mowed down from time to time by the plague, or other devastating epidemics. In this way they escaped many of the diseases not only of old age but of advanced middle life. Again, it must not be forgotten that each generation represented to a much larger extent than is now the case the survival of the fittest. Most of the weaklings died in childhood. The triumph of modern hygiene is, that it has preserved a large proportion of these lives; on this we may fairly pride ourselves from the humanitarian point of view, but we must not shut our eyes to the fact that it has the serious drawback of lowering the general standard of health,and of sapping the vigour of the race. Another factor which must be taken into account in estimating the prevalence of diseases is our vastly greater power of recognising them. Discussing this question in an article which recently appeared in the "Nouvelle Revue," Dr. P.L. Hauser says:-

"What then is the cause of the multiplication of disease? Is this multiplication merely apparent, being due first to the progress of natural science and then to the new knowledge which we have obtained with reference to pathology? While the fact of this new knowledge is indisputable this last hypothesis is insufficient to explain the absolute silence, maintained by the most distinguished physicians of past years, with reference to a great many of the diseases of our epoch. While biological science has made immense strides in recent years, we cannot deny to the physicians of ancient times a profound spirit of observation. Yet we look in vain for the least mention of diseases such as diphteria, progressive locomotor ataxia, progressive muscular atrophy, Parkinson's disease, Basedow's disease, general paralysis of the insane, and the different sorts of cerebrospinal sclerosis, all of which are frequent to-day."

Dr. Hauser's remark is, the "Practitioner" thinks, too sweeping. A very fair description of diphtheria is to be found in Aretaeus. It is by no means safe to infer, because no mention is to be found in old writers of diseases of obscure and perplexing symptomatology, that they did not exist. This argument would equally prove that many other diseases are of modern development. Round ulcer of the stomach was so utterly unknown in the seventeenth century, that the discovery of the lesion at the postmortem examination of the body of a Royall princess was held to be a proof of poisoning, and for political reasons was explained away as the result of an awkward use of the scissors. Appendicitis again may be more common now than formerly, but we know that it did exist long before it was generally recognised, and it may fairly be assumed that it has existed since man had an appendix. Yet there is no mentionn of it in the ancient writers.

div.head: AUSTRIA IN MACEDONIA.
div.p: There are four conflicting purposes which divide the European Powers on the question of Macedonia. The first is that of Great Britain, who is followed by France and Italy. It is altruistic and recognises that Macedonia should be freed from the Sultan. The second is the cynical policy of Germany, who desires to be friends with the Sultan, and is, therefore, hostile to the altruisic idea. The third was that of Russia before the war, which consisted in urging on Bulgaria to war with Turkey so that she might step in and promote a rec-ification of frontiers to her own advantage. The fourth policy is that of Austria, whose people are closely in contact with the Macedonians, whose traders have been first on the spot, and whose capitalists have acquired great interests in the country. As Mr. R. A. Scott-James points out in the "Fortnightly Review," Austria has nothing to gain by any sudden change in the Government of Macedonia, for if the present state of things continues, her securities in the country, and consequently her control of the country, will be such that she will have practically absorbed Macedonia, as Russia was in process of absorbing Macedonia, as Russia was in process of absorbing Manchuria. Peace and order are necessary to her plans, and she desires just so much reform as will stave off revolution without destroying the supremacy of the Porte. Austria has so far won all along the line, for the other five Powers, Russia owing to her misfortunes, have all waived their own policies and played into her hands, while the unfortunate people of Macedonia have continued to be the pawns of diplomatists.

div.head: ROMAN CATHOLICS IN THE EAST. FRENCH PROTECTORATE RENOUNCED.
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that the Superior of the Italian Mission of the Franciscans, Father Joseph Caneve, celebrated a Requiem Mass there for the victims of the earthquakes in Calabria, in the presence of the Italian Ambassador and Consul-General, the officers of the Italian guardship, and the members of the Italian colony. It will be remembered that Father Caneve, in obedience to the orders of the Vatican, informed the French Ambassador at Constantinople, in September last, that being unwilling any longer to remain under the Protectorate of France he had placed himself under the Protectorate of Italy. The other religious missions sent their Superiors to the Requiem Mass, which inaugurated the taking possession of the Italian missions at Constantinople by the Italian Ambassador.

div.head: BRITAIN AND ITS NEIGHBOURS
div.p: The "Edinburgh Review" takes a hopeful view of the future relations of the Powers. In sober truth, it remarks, is there reasonable ground for anticipating the occurrence of a life-and-death struggle between the British Empire and a combination against it of the great nations of the Continent? Is it quite rational to anticipate a future in which the United Kingdom, the centre of the commerce of the whole world, will be perforce entirely dependent upon its internal resources, and will glare out, so to speak, from behind its moat, and with its drawbridges raised, against millions of encircling foes panting for its de- struction? It is sufficiently lamentable that in the early years of the twentieth century so gloomy a prospect should loom before the eyes of Englishmen. We have, assuredly, no right to calculate on perpetual peace. It is possible on the other hand, to give too much rein to the imagination in picturing the dangers of the coming years. . . . When we take a general survey of our own position in either hemi- sphere, we are quite unable to see that it necessitates the taking of such gigantic mea- sures as are recommended to us. Lord Roberts is unjust in suggesting that the British people are either indifferent to military matters or that they are unwilling to make sacrifices. But reasonable men ought at least carefully to weigh the real danger of their condition before they saddle themselves with burdens which must greatly hamper the growth and prosperity of the people.

div.head: SUDANESE BELIEFS AS TO WHITE MENS ORIGIN.
div.p: There is a passage in one of the ancient Arab histories in which the statement is made that "the white people come from the other side of the sea," and that perfectly plain and intelligible statement has been so distorted that the belief widely prevailed throughout the Western Sudan that white men oame from the bottom of the ses. This belief has been found to exi-t both in British and b Frenbh territory. It was, indeed, on one occasion turned somewhat ingeniously to aoooant by a Pulani Emir whore country was situated some dis- tance from the Niger. In the early days of our occupation of the Niger territory onr activity was, for obvious reasons, oonfioed to the imme- diate neighborhood of the river.Tbis was held strong confirmation ot the theory as to the origin of 'he white man, and the Bmir in ques- tion aotnally informed his sabjeots, who were growing distarbed at the stories they bad heard of the white man’s prowess, that they had nothing to fear from the white men. *s they oonld hot lire away from the water I The taot that a high official took his tub daily was farther considered confirmatory evidence of the submarine origin of the white men. There can be no donbt, also, that the Arabs, in order to ratab their bfluence over the natives, spread broadoast the statement that the white men were cannibals. The fact that, they did not eat black men was explained as due to their devilish onnniog. They wanted . to make themselves strong in the oountry before beginning their horrid praotioes; but, | as they c >nld not altogether do without this kind of food, they brought homao flash with them in tins. Thus were the tinned meats of the white man made to support this weird j invention. It was only when his men refused 1 to eat the remains of a tin ot meat of whioh he had himself partaken that a well-known | explorer at lougth learned the legend. Tbii was in Bast Central Africa, but in West i Africa a French expedition had the unfor- tunate experience of finding a portion of a | human huger—cut off, no donbt, by some aooident—in a tin of meat Here was fresh and conclusive confirmation of the story, b whioh the people had almost oeased to believe, | and it was only after a considerable lapse of time that the idea was at length eradicated.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair plad to all, to permit- within certain ---- limits- --- discussion. DERIVATION OF THE WORD "GALABIEH."
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Sir,—Can any of your readers kindly enlight- en me as to the correct derivation of the common word “Galabieh"? Theliterary form is said to be gulbab, plural, guldbeeb.

By chance I came across the following quotation in a Latin dictionary :- "Lebitonarium est colobium sine manicis quali monachi Egyptu utuntur," - the lebitonarium is a robe without sleeves, such as Egyptian monks wear. )Isidor. Orig. 7th century).
on tracing colobium to the Greek lexican we find, of course, kolos, kolobos, - curtailed, shortened, and kolobion, an under garment with short sleeves.
Is it possible that the Arabs, after their conquest of this country in the seventh century, adopted the native smock, and altered "kolobion" into "galabieh"?

I have never been able to account for the double "b" in gulbab, galdbeeb. Was this literary form invented by Arabian lexicographers in the hope that the word might be taken to be of pure Arab origin?- You obedient servant,
INQUIRER.
Cairo, 13th November.

div.p: Commodore Somerville Nicholson, of the United States Navy, in a letter from 1887 R. Street,Northwest, Washington, D.C., says:

"Your Peruna has been and is now used by so many of my friends and acquaintances are sure cure for catarrh that I am convinced of its curative qualities and I unhesitatingly recommend it to all persons suffering from that complaint."
Our army and our navy are the natural protection of our country.
Peruna is the natural protection of the army and navy in the vicissitudes of climate and exposure.

div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER. (From our Correspondent).
div.p: Paris, November 8.

Paris has at last definitely accepted the fact that we are within measurable distance of winter, and although one still sees plenty of people seated outside of the cafes at the â€¢absinthe hoor,â€ one ro longer, except at the favorite establishments where there is a first- rate orchestra and mnch life and animation, has tho same ditlicolty in obtaining a seat on the terrace.

The Kaiser is disappointed because France has not responded to bis advances. Alsace- Lorraine is, as he perceives, a barrier to a close entente. Ail sorts of suggestions have been made by way of solving the thorny problem, but the latest, whioh emanates, as osual, from a Teutonic source, is so very eocentrio that it really deserves mention. The Emperor would, if this idea were adopted, put the following proposition before the two peoples : Lorraine to be restored to Franoe, who, in return, wonld hand over to Germany Corsica, the southern portion of Madagascar, and Cambodia, it being farther stipulated that neither Power should keep a garrison within twenty-five miles of its frontier. The notion that the French would give up Corsica to the Germans, having them as sooth-eastern, as well as eastern, neighbours, and allowing them to get in the thin end of the wedge in Madagarcarand their lodo China territory, is too unpractical to deserve serious attention for a moment. After all that has recently occurred in oonneotion with Morocco, the suggestion that such a delicate question should be submitted to a referendum of tie two nationsâ€”a step which would be bound to iuoreaÂ«e agitation to fever-heatâ€”stands te'f- oendemned.

As a matter of fact, numbers of thoughtful French and German people, who have devoted much consideration to the still vexed question of the lost provinces, have had to confess themselves bstiled by its magnitude. ' Vive TAlsace-Lorraine Frar^iise !" are words that figure prominently on the address issned, in which the League of Patriots invited lovers of their country to join in welcoming M. Paul DEroulEde on his arrival in Paris on Sunday afternoon, and its president, who has returned after his long exile, will certaialy do his at- most to prevent any of bis fellow citizens who may be halting betwoen two opioions from supporting any movement for the conclusion of a close entente with Germany.

M. de Lanessan contributes to this morn- ing's "Sifcole" an artiole on the recent toasts of the German Emperor nnder the title "Cresarian Speeches." He dwells on them as being timely demonstrations for the ontand-ont French internationalists, of tho argent need of putting France in ajiroper state of defence. Who can tell, he asks, how far such an antocrat as the German Emperor may go either to please the German war party or to satisfy bis own "Middle Age feelirgit" If his'threats are meant for Franoe, they are quite unjustifiable, for Franoe has done everything in her power since the inexplicable visit to Tangier to be agreeable to Germany while manifesting a sincere desire for peaoe M. de Lanessan con- siders that Frenchmen are entitled to think it very 'singular that Germany should fail to understand the real extent of the saorifioea Franoe has made in acquiescing in the depar- ture of M. DalcassE at tho book and oall of a foreign Power. The German Emperorâ€™s persistent bellicose outbursts are in strange contrast with the protests of friendship in which he formerly indulged. Yet Franoe has never changed her attitude towards Germany.

The entente with England, which is the real motive of William Il.â€™a ill-hnmoor, ought never, argues M. de Lsnessau, to have aroused bis suspicious or provoked German hostility. Like the Franoo-Rusaian allianoe, the entente with Bngland is a necessary guarantee ot peace. It is a mutual precaution against sventual aggression, and how can William II. hope to oonvince any one that France or Bngland intends to at'aok Germany. If the Kaiser sincerely desired pesos he ought to rejoice at the alliance and understandings, but this is manifestly not his state of mind. He is violently opposed to the Anglo, Frenoh entente, and his recent speeches were directed asainst this entente. Ha wonld have been well inspired not to have delivered them. They give to his conduct ao aggressive appearance which is all the more disquieting because his temperament is so ardent, his authority is a'most absolote, his army is eager to fight, and his people are too submissive to reaot against the fantasies and the impulsive spirit of the Cm tar. He may fancy that he is merely indulging in a little lyrio poetry, but it is im- possible for his neighbours to accept this in- terpretation of language directly menacing them. They, too, feel that it is necessary to hold themselves in readiness, for, while de- termined not to attack, they are no less resolved to defend themselves vigorously against attacks of which they might be the object.

Like its elder brother Parliament (in the throee of interpellations Ibis afternoon), the City Council bssgot to work after its holidays. The' Marioâ€ las leen questioning the mem- bers as to their impressions of London. It is the organisation of city life that teems prin- cipally to appeaL Thiy are struck with the centralisation of electrical power, with the tramway system, with the swift-moving little omnibuses, with the independence of oity government in relation to the higher powers, and with Robert, the London policeman. Robert stands for dignity, for British suavity combined with the â€˜â€˜fortiter in re." The visitors note with astonishment the obedience of the oabmsn to the white gloved hand of the man in bine. In Paris they argne with author- ity, and it ia only after epithets are exhausted that the "cooher"deigns too move"higher up." It is a nice command of language that is wanted in the police here, and a real ability to be angry so as to impress the crowd. After Robert, the cabs are the orowniog point of London, if we are to telieve the Paris Coun- cillor. The attenuated "gees" of the Boule- vards make no showing beside the oavalry of the Strand.

French doveootea have at last achieved a position of practical utility higher than that of flying matches for fancy prize'. Among the scattered French garrison of the Saharan oases, a dovecote is a permanent part of the equipment, and should telegraphic wires or wireless installation fail, the remotest of the detachments could still commonioate by wing- ed courier with Constantine, Oran, Algiers, as well as with the Moroccan frontier strongholds, and even with Tangier. In case of hostilities, the pigeon post wonld render important service to the flying columr.s. The French North Sea fulling fleet which plies from the Dogger Bank to the Scilly Inlands, is also to be staffed with a pigeon post for daily service, giving infotma- tion of the working resalts and of the state of the orews. The Navy Department is also taking action.

The Frenoh League for the Suppression o Dust on Public Roads still continues its la- bours, undiscouraged by the scant measure of practical success which has up to the present attended its operations. The aims of ihs League are essentially humanitarian, and as soch its work was brought to the notice of tho Anti- tubenuIoMs Congress. Still more to familiarise the world with its methods, the League a few days ago conduoted a largo party of foreign jonrnalists, representing every capital in Eu- rope, over some of the worst roads in the Frenoh capital, where they saw tho League's various methods of dusâ€˜-layiog at work. The tests and experiments formed a highly interest- ing series.

A great tram formation is contemplated in the telephone system of Paris. The snbjeot has been investigated in great thoroughness and detail by an administrative committee of 30 members, who have drafted a comjlete read- justment of the service. Their scheme involves the adoption of all the most recent scientific improvements. The necessary works will require two years, and will entail an outlay of Â£400,000. One ot the minor improvements to be adopted is an aatomatio central call and ring-off battery. The scheme has been approv- ed by the Government.

The monopoly of the tobaoco trade, which is the property of the Government in Franoe, brings in an enormouB revenue to the State, and enables pensions to be given, without trenching on the taxes, to those who have deserved well of their ooontry either in person, or, as ia more frequent, through a father or a husband. The French Minister of Finanoe has just made his annual distribution of the vacant bureaux de tabac, and, as is usually the esse, most of the recipients are womenâ€”widows or daoghters of soldiers, sailors, or civilian offi- cials. Only one man appears in the list, and he is M. Germain, who was formerly the deputy for Lorraine in the German Reichstag, but who now lives in Franoe, and appears to have fallen on evil days. Among the women who have received the envied shops are the grand- daughter and danghter of a deputy, two wi- dows and a daughter of generals, the daughter of a prefect, the widow ofa judge, the daughter ot a Minister Plenipotentiary, and so on. These posts are eagerly sought after, and they enable the Government to provide a means of sub- sistence to widows and orphans by a privileged mode of earning a living. It is a very ingenious scheme, but more suited to French ideas than to ours, as we should think it rather humiliat- ing for the widow of a general or of an ambas- sador to keep a tobacco shop, althoogh we are twitted with being a nation of shopkeepers.

The children weep ; Footit is mad. Not to know Footit is to argue that yon do not know the real pleasures of Parisâ€”the Nouveau Cirque, for example. Footit was the down of this establishment for twenty years. Ho has contributed more than any poblio entertainer to the joy of little men and maidens. The oomi- calitiee of Footit have become a legend with "lee enfante de jendiâ€™â€™â€” so named because Thursday is the childrenâ€™s matinEe, the day when pietty mammas take their rosebuds to witness the drolleries of Footit and Chooolat and the wonders of the performing dog."Grown- nps"did not disdain to smile at Footit; indeed, they roared. Who could h?Ip it T He was irre- sistible*. The.saddest man forgot his gloom whdn face to face with this ineffable buffoon. Nature made him funny to look opon ;art made him fannier still. His gestores were amasing, and bis â€œpatter" was replete with wit Occasionally h j said a memorable thing which passed from month to month like the sayings of the anoient sage. The fineit thing he invented was Chooolat Chocolat was his companion in l he ring. He is a negro. That very rame, "Chooolat," which Footit gave him, was in the oat ore of a precious legacy. It is a â– ame to live up to It immediately appealed to the small patrons of the circos-Tbey knew their Chooolat; be was grateful and comforting, and they ioiiated on having him.

Chooolat has passed into the language, not merely as something to eat or drink, but a# expressing the idea of being viotimisei. "J'ai EtE ohooolat" means that yon were badly "taken in,â€ or cruelly dealt with in some manner. The expression arose from the circumstance that Chooolat's mission in life wasto reoeive the buffs tings of Footit He was the foil of Footit Daring the twenty years of his professional existence at the circus Footit had one real romance. As a sort cf habit proper to all downs, he threw kisses to the Equestrienne, who jamped through hoops of fire and alighted on the horse's tail with the agility of her race. Bat one day this professional declaration tam- ed into the real thing. Footit became in love. He left the oirons to get over it When he returned, he had a species of triumph. Now he has lost his reason, poor fellow, and is interned at Lisbon, whither he had wandered after his eogsgement had oonolnded in Paris. Chooolat saunters sadly along the Boulevard' saying it is not true. He refases to believe it You will be proud to think that Footit is an English- man. He laboured before M. Loubet or M. DelcassE or anybody fir the Entente, and the â€˜ good understanding" is the motley of the clown.

It ia already known that the winei of 1906 will not be anything like in the front rank, bnt the fall results of the French vintage have only just bEen published by the "Moni- tour Vinicole." It appears that the wines are not only poor in quality, bat considerably less in quantity than last year, for the total prodaouon of Franoe and Algeria this aotomn is one thousand million gallons against one thousand fonr hundred million gallons last year. This falling off is doe dm fly to cryptoga- mous diseases and to mildew, the Departments prindpally affected being those in Eastern France. In Menrthe-et-Moselle, Meuse, and the Vosges the vintage has almost completely failed, but in some parts of Franoe the orop is larger than last year, for example, in the Cflte-d'Or, SaOno-et Loire.and Dordogne, where the output shows a considerable increase. Both Algeria and Corsica have fallen off, and it ia safe to Bay that very few brands of 1905 will appear in the wine lists of the fatnre. With nearly three hundred million gallons less wine produce 1, and that in large measure of interior quality, the vintage of this antnmn will have to fijnre on the wine card among the cheaper sorts, which are not accorded the honor of a name and a date by the wine- merchants.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY (From our Correspondent).
div.p: London, November 4.
To day the 8.3. Doners left Southampton with artillery and infantry drafts on board for Bpypt, Ceylon, Singapore, and Hung Kong. The liner is doe at Port Said on the 17th inst.

The vacant majority in the Rifls Brigade has been filled by the promotion of Captain and Brevet Lientenant-Coloned G. H. The- siger, who is presently the senior rffijer in obarge of Musketry at Salisbury Plain. Li eat-Col. Thesiger joined the "Green-jackets" in Maroh, 1890, and was adjutant of the 2nd Battalion in the Khartoum Expedition, 1890 (mentioned in despatohes, brevet majority, medal, Khedive's medal with olasp), anl with the same battalion he shared in the defence of Ladysmith, and was severely wounded in the battle of the 6th January, (mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, medal with olasps).

Captain R. G. Stirling, King's Royal Rifle Corps, latterly employed as a company oom- mander in the 1st Battalion Kingâ€™s Afrioan R'flee, has retired from the service after spend- ing rather less than seven years in it He served with the 1st Battalion, now in Egypt at he actions of Talana Hill and Lombard's Kop, and the defenoe of Ladysmith, and the operations in the Eastern Transvaal, 1901-2 (medal with four clasps).
Lieutenant-Colonel Gerald M. Mackenzie, commanding the 1st Battalion Royal Innis- killing Fusiliers, at Belfast, has been pro- moted brevet-colonel on completing three years in his rank.

Sanction has been given for the employ- ment of Captain E.M.G. MoFerran, 4th Bat- talion Royal Irish Rifles, for a farther tour of service with the Kingâ€™s Afrioan Rifles, to complete five years with that force.
J. S. Purdy, M.D., F.R.G.S., of the Egyptian Quarantine Servioe,retains his rank of Surgeon Captain of the New Zealand Militia.

Five ooean-going "destroyersâ€ of a new type are to be built in private yards for the Royal Navy ia the oomiog year. The details are neoessarily meagre, but it is understood that speed will be a great desideratum. They will be designed to steam 83 koots per hour. This ia a practical condemnation of the eub- atantially built but slower 25-knotter* of the "River" olaas. The five will be named Afridi, Gbuika, Tartar, Cossack, and Mohawk. The Afridi and Gburka will be built by Arm- strong, Mitchell, and Co., Newcastle-on-Tyne ; the Tartar, by Thorneycroft and Ca; Mohawk, by Messrs. White and Co., C iwaa, and Cossack by Cammell, Laird, and Co., Birkenhead.

The announcement that Messrs. Yarrow â€”a firm famed for thip-bnildiog and fast tor- pedo boats - are dosing their yard at Poplar and going to the North, has fallen like the proverbial bomb shell in the eastern parts of the Metropolis. The firm employ 1,200 hands and pay something like Â£2,000 a week in wages. Mr. Yarrow says one of the reasons is the high rates prevailing in Poplsr, amount- ing to 12s. in the Â£, and now the firmâ€™s machinery is also rated, the harden of the municipal exactions has fco.ome intolerable. Yarrow's will probably go to the North- East, where wares as well are cheaper. â€˜The pnblio ot the North of Bogland,â€ Mr. Yarrow says, "are more frugal and thrifty than in London, and devote less time to pleasore and amusement than is the case here. Con- sequently yon get a better class of em- ployes all roond. The same love of pleasore pervades all dasses of aodety in London, from the highest to the lowest, and the pro- portion of time and study given to pleasure as compared with work, is all on the side of pleamre. There ia not the slightest ohanoe of Yarrow's remaining on the Thames. If the firm do not leave, they say they will go into the bankroptoy oonrt They mean to try the North first.

Never, in the most intolerant days, were religions polemics fought out with more bitter- ness th\n are military nowadays. The war of creeds is as nothing to that of the schemes and systems advocated for the perfeotiog of oor institutions. Every ore, since the Sooth Afrioan war, has his own panaces, and derides all others. Failure then was referred to various causes; seldom, if ever, to the right one ; and suggested remedial have been pnt forward for all with no resalt bat increasing confusion and the continual postponement of reform. The truth is that the word reform is a misnomer, and the orying need for it has never been made out explicitly. Once again we must emphasise the real desideratum. We want means, not methods ; the latter will serve, always, if the former are forthoomiog. They were wholly inadequate in the last crisis, and they will assuredly be the same in the next, so long as repeated experiment and increasing obange in machinery are plaoed firat in our requirements. We a*e for e\er asking some- thing new instead of acoepting some plau- sible, even possible, theory and giving it a chanoe. The public, in its restlessness, is like a man perpetually pulling off a ban- dage to look at his wounded leg. Plaster of Paris is the proper treatment, and a period of absolute rest and qnieeoence is most needed. We may not agree with the present Secre- tary of Stateâ€™s pet proposals, and yet jn common fairness let os give them a trial. Just now be is being taken rather unduly to task ; be is taxed with ioaoonracy and mis- leading statement. We decline to believe the results alleged to have been achieved for the new long-servioe enlistment; we soont all hope of obtaining a short-service army. The malcontents may be perfectly right, bnt they have still to prove their case. It is wiser, sorely, to hear what facts are addooed by the authorities in their defence, and wait till we get chapter and verse in the shape of official figures about which there oan be no misunderstanding.
